story.kicker_image_caption: The 'lost city' isn't a city at all. Source: University of Athens
story.storykicker: A study published in Journal of Marine and Petroleum Geology reveals that the "clusters of cobblestones and symmetrical stone cylinders" found undersea near the island of Zakynthos are not human-made at all.
story.storybody:
When you're a fiction lover, you stumble upon tales about lost cities and references to Atlantica quite often. You cannot help but wonder if there is actually a lost, forgotten land lying somewhere on a seabed, or in the pits of a volcano...

To someone that hopeful, this piece of news might be a little saddening. Mysterious structures discovered under the sea near the Greek island of Zakynthos has been crossed off the list of being a possible ancient city.

A study published in Journal of Marine and Petroleum Geology on Thursday reveals that the blocks which look like "cobblestone paving and bases for pillars" are not human-made at all.

{mosimage}


Is it an alien-architected civilisation, then?

Eh, no.

These structures, which may seem like ruins of ancient pillars and squares, were actually build by bacteria.

Yes, you read it right. Bacteria.

When archaeologists took a dip to inspect the site, they noticed there were no signs of coins, pottery fragments and other things which confirm the existence of a human civilisation.

"There's no other evidence, nothing that suggests human civilisation," Environmental scientist Julian Andrews told Smithsonian.com. "There's no pottery, no coins, nothing else that usually goes along with these things."

After analysing the mineral contents of these underwater structures, they came to the conclusion that these were built by the microorganisms.

Hold on, there's more.

{mosimage}


How did bacteria make these "structures"?

Very simple. Bowel movement.

The archaeologists discovered that these structures contain a mineral called dolomite; a calcium byproduct produced by methane-consuming bacteria.

Basically, what happened - a long time ago - is the bacteria found a natural source of methane in this area under the sea. This led to the production of dolomite, a cement-like component, which settled down to form these structures.

These structures appear to be about 2.6 million years old and are not unique. Similar sites have been found in California's Monterey Bay, the Gulf of Cadiz in the Mediterranean, and in the North Sea.

Thus, what once amazed people into believing that they had found a lost city, was actually a bunch of blocks built from bacteria excreta.

{mosimage}
story.magazinekicker: A study published in Journal of Marine and Petroleum Geology reveals that the "clusters of cobblestones and symmetrical stone cylinders" found undersea near the island of Zakynthos are not human-made at all.
story.shortheadline: Here's the story of the 'lost underwater city' that wasn't built by humans

briefcase_content.briefcase: Archaeologists says structures found undersea near island Zakynthos are not part of a 'lost city'.
No evidence of human civilization was found here.
These structures appear to be about 2.6 million years old and are not unique.

metatags.keywords: Lost underwater city,Lost undersea city not build by humans,Zakynthos,Bacteria build lost city,Bacteria
